story:
Our Project: Documenting the Voices of Freedom from Inside Burma's Revolution of the Spirit as She Transitions from Dictatorship to Democracy.  

                     Thank you Beautiful People. Thank you for caring about Burma,

                                  freedom, and being the best that we can be. 

                                 

 

       You are Invited to Play a Vital Role in the Creation of this not-for-profit Project

For an Expanded New Edition of the book The Voice of Hope: Aung San Suu Kyi

"Every leader on the planet should read this book at least once."

~ Alice Walker, Pulitzer-Prize winning author of The Color Purple 

Burma (called Myanmar, by some) is undergoing one of the most epic reforms in human history: after decades of authoritarian military rule we're seeing the dawn of a compassion-inspired democracy born from love and nonviolence.  

This next phase of Burma’s "revolution of the spirit" is  being led by former political prisoners, artists and dissidents, including Nobel Peace laureate, Aung San Suu Kyi, “an icon of democracy...all around the world,” as declared by President Barack Obama during his historic visit to Burma just days after his reelection. 

Freed after spending the better part of 20 years under house arrest and prison, Aung San Suu Kyi, a recently elected Parliamentarian within her country’s new civilian Government, has called upon freedom-loving people everywhere, to SUPPORT Burma NOW, more than ever.   

"As spiritual and political beings we are all activists at heart. No one is outside of society...It's about our freedom. That means everybody. We must see that nothing and no one is separate from this freedom. No one is an island in this world." ~ Aung San Suu Kyi 

 Our Intention, Our Hope

 

We are a team of "freedom-lovers" passionate about travelling to Burma, the heart of this radical transition. Our intention is to document the insights and stories of the less known leaders in their long march toward freedom: former political prisoners; dissident writers, musicians, journalists, filmmakers, poets and comedians; Buddhist monks and nuns; reformed government leaders; shop owners; returning refugees; farmers; students; and possibly Aung San Suu Kyi herself, along with her esteemed colleagues, mentors and teachers.

The Why?

Aung San Suu Kyi's message has been consistent from the time she entered politics: “Be free. Nobody can imprison your mind. They can imprison your body, but they cannot imprison your mind. We must always remember this. Free your mind.”

But how? How have the people done this for the past 24 years of revolution? That is precisely what we want to ask these courageous activists and more, and in so doing, bring their voices of freedom out from Burma into the world.

These revolutionary voices - the many expressions of the strength and effectiveness of nonviolent strategy - are a GIFT to us all and will support  the struggles for freedom going on in so many other places in the world today, and in our own hearts and minds as well. 

  We must ACT quickly

Due to logistical complexities and the fragility of the transition in Burma, our clock is ticking. Our desire is to be in country by late-January. In service of that goal thank you from the depths of our hearts for your generous support.   

      

The Impact

The (New) Voice of Hope will not only carry Aung San Suu Kyi's illuminated vision, in which politics and spirituality are inseparable, it will for the first time bring forth the courageous stories of many other freedom fighters from over two decades of nonviolent resistance. Together they will inspire a conciliatory message for all of humanity along with an impassioned call for international action to safeguard global human rights and the environment. That is, Aung San Suu Kyi maintains, “if enough of us become voices of hope ourselves.”

This PROJECT is in solidarity with the Occupy movements, the Arab Spring, the student strikes, the immolations in Tibet, and austerity demonstrations the world over. We feel that Burma’s long struggle for freedom, human rights and democracy is a beacon offering a fresh model for global transformation.

For those who make a contribution, this is a unique opportunity to invest in spreading the vital message and strategy of nonviolence to a global audience.

"Every thought, every word, and every action that adds to the positive and the wholesome is a contribution to peace. Each and every one of us is capable of making such a contribution. Let us join hands to try to create a peaceful world where we can sleep in security and wake in happiness."

- Aung San Suu Kyi

Thank you helping us to achieve the vision - joining your hands with ours.

 

      

Our Team

Alan Clements: Among the first Westerners to ordain as a Buddhist monk in Burma, Alan lived in a monastery for nearly five years training in meditation under the Venerable Mahasi Sayadaw and his successor Sayadaw U Pandita. 

After leaving monastic life he became active in Burma’s struggle for freedom, authoring (and co-authoring) several books on their nonviolent revolution for democracy while raising international awareness through the media, including ABC’s Nightline, CBS News, Time and Newsweek, the Guardian, as well as  delivering a keynote for Amnesty International’s 30th year anniversary.

After 16 years of being blacklisted from Burma for his writings and activism, he was recently “unblacklisted” by Burma’s President. And just days ago, he was granted “official permission” to re-enter the country! 

Summer Starr: Summer has extensive experience as an activist, international speaker, legal observer, environmental lobbyist, organizer in student movements, the Occupy movement in NYC, and across the country. She holds a Masters Degree in Environmental Law and Policy from Vermont Law School, a Masters Degree in Indigenous Politics from the University of Hawai'i, and was a candidate for a District Seat in the Hawaii State House of Representatives.

Marcia Jacobs: Over the past two decades working as a social worker and trauma therapist, Marcia has been creating programs for refugees in conflict and post conflict situations in Bosnia, Kosovo, Afghanistan and Darfur, through The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, UNICEF, and various NGOs, including the International Rescue Committee, founded by Albert Einstein in response to the plight of refugees after WWII. 

Ian MacKenzie: Ian is a new media producer based in Vancouver, BC. He has a background in video journalism, short films, and documentaries, with his work appearing in The New York Times, National Geographic TV, CBC Documentary, The Globe and Mail, Adbusters, and festivals around the world. He is currently co-producing Occupy Love, and is in post-production for the short film Reactor. Ian’s short film The Revolution Is Love was named one of the top 10 Occupy films to watch 2011. 

    

 What we need and how your funds will be spent:

10% of contributions go to feeding the monks and nuns and to an HIV/AIDS clinic in Yangon.

Our priority is to be radically transparent in all that we do. We've broken our  costs down for you below so that when you contribute to this vision you know precisely how your funds will be used.

Our Initial Goal: $25,000  

Step 1: Getting to Burma

Flights r/t: $2,350 / Accommodation:$450 / Ground transport $100 

Gifts for hosts and supporters in Burma past and present: $2000     

As a service based vision, no funds are allocated for salaries or stipends.

Step 2: 28 Days in Burma documenting the Voices of Freedom

Accommodation: $2,800 / Food: $1,800 / Transportation: $1,800 / Translator: $2,800 / Medical: $1000 / Internet/phone: $500 / Internal flights $800

Media: Tablet, recorder, two mics: $2,500 / three 128 gb memory cards  $600. / two 1 TB hard drives: $400 / SD Cards: $ 200 / Contingency Tech Needs: $400.   

Indiegogo’s share of funds, pay pal and credit card processing fees $2,000.

And 10% goes to feed the monks and nuns and to an HIV/AIDS clinic in Yangon to buy food, blankets, mosquito nets, and medicines.

Second Tier Goal: $35,000 

Alan spent six months in Burma in 1995 when producing the original edition of “The Voice of Hope.” The initial $25,000 is just the beginning of this project, covering the most basic costs of a 28 day stay in Burma. In other words, every dollar received beyond $25,000 grants us the privilege of continuing to document as many Voices of Freedom as possible. Thus preserving the priceless insights on nonviolent revolution from some of the most courageous activists alive.    

In addition, we need several full time professionals to transcribe the interviews and a couple of great audio/ video editors. In addition, we need a talented web developer and graphic artist. But for now, we're hoping that we can fill these roles with volunteers or interns who can work with us virtually.

If interested in offering your services please email us your resume today! Thank you.   

Third Tier Stretch Funding: $50,000 + 

Funding at this level will radically expedite the project by securing the services of a production manager, quality book designer, researchers, copy editors, a photo archivist and caption writer, social media expert, and a radical publicist. 

From our hearts, thank you for believing in us and partnering with us to bring "Burma’s Voices of Freedom" to the world now ...and for generations to come.   

        

Additional Ways You Can Help

Beyond monetarily supporting this vision, there are a number of other ways to help us to bring Burma's voices of hope and freedom to the world.  

1. Campaign Ambassadors: We need inspired hearts willing to spread the word of our Campaign worldwide. Please reach out through your personal email lists and social networks and circles, inspiring friends, family and co-workers to join this ACTION, this worldwide peaceful revolution for freedom. 

If you'd like to work with us on a more full time basis please email today.

2. Tech Talents: We would like talented volunteers in the following areas:

* Transcribing interviews 

* Editing interviews 

* Researchers (especially, those who are knowledgeable about Burma)

* Graphic artists (and those skilled in designing book interiors & covers)

* Researching photographs for the book and getting clearances for use 

* Copy editors (print)

* Audio and video editors  

* Web developer (s): talented coders / word press / drupal 7  

* Calling for a brilliant publicist to bring this publication to the world.

3. Calling all Members of the Media: Please carry this story, whether blogs, newspapers, campus circulations, PSA's on community radio or "live reads" by DJ's everywhere in the world. All we ask is that you communicate the vision in a way that reflects unity, reconciliation and hope for ALL the people of Burma. 

Please, print any aspect of anything you see on our site and spread the word.

JOIN US! Have a talent we need? Want to be a part of the movement?

Send us a simple resumé. We will get back to you quickly.  

From Our Hearts thank you...

The book - BRINGING BURMA'S VOICES OF FREEDOM TO THE WORLD - will be a POWERFUL resource for anyone interested in practicing global human rights, environmental sanity and the universal right to be free. 

Please help us make this happen!
story_txt:
Our Project: Documenting the Voices of Freedom from Inside Burma's Revolution of the Spirit as She Transitions from Dictatorship to Democracy.  
                     Thank you Beautiful People. Thank you for caring about Burma,
                                  freedom, and being the best that we can be. 
                                 
 
       You are Invited to Play a Vital Role in the Creation of this not-for-profit Project
For an Expanded New Edition of the book The Voice of Hope: Aung San Suu Kyi
"Every leader on the planet should read this book at least once." 
~ Alice Walker, Pulitzer-Prize winning author of The Color Purple 

Burma (called Myanmar, by some) is undergoing one of the most epic reforms in human history: after decades of authoritarian military rule we're seeing the dawn of a compassion-inspired democracy born from love and nonviolence.  
This next phase of Burma’s "revolution of the spirit" is  being led by former political prisoners, artists and dissidents, including Nobel Peace laureate, Aung San Suu Kyi, “an icon of democracy...all around the world,” as declared by President Barack Obama during his historic visit to Burma just days after his reelection. 
Freed after spending the better part of 20 years under house arrest and prison, Aung San Suu Kyi, a recently elected Parliamentarian within her country’s new civilian Government, has called upon freedom-loving people everywhere, to SUPPORT Burma NOW, more than ever.   
"As spiritual and political beings we are all activists at heart. No one is outside of society...It's about our freedom. That means everybody. We must see that nothing and no one is separate from this freedom. No one is an island in this world." ~ Aung San Suu Kyi 

 Our Intention, Our Hope

 
We are a team of "freedom-lovers" passionate about travelling to Burma, the heart of this radical transition. Our intention is to document the insights and stories of the less known leaders in their long march toward freedom: former political prisoners; dissident writers, musicians, journalists, filmmakers, poets and comedians; Buddhist monks and nuns; reformed government leaders; shop owners; returning refugees; farmers; students; and possibly Aung San Suu Kyi herself, along with her esteemed colleagues, mentors and teachers.
The Why?
Aung San Suu Kyi's message has been consistent from the time she entered politics: “Be free. Nobody can imprison your mind. They can imprison your body, but they cannot imprison your mind. We must always remember this. Free your mind.”
But how? How have the people done this for the past 24 years of revolution? That is precisely what we want to ask these courageous activists and more, and in so doing, bring their voices of freedom out from Burma into the world.
These revolutionary voices - the many expressions of the strength and effectiveness of nonviolent strategy - are a GIFT to us all and will support  the struggles for freedom going on in so many other places in the world today, and in our own hearts and minds as well. 
  We must ACT quickly
Due to logistical complexities and the fragility of the transition in Burma, our clock is ticking. Our desire is to be in country by late-January. In service of that goal thank you from the depths of our hearts for your generous support.   
       
The Impact
The (New) Voice of Hope will not only carry Aung San Suu Kyi's illuminated vision, in which politics and spirituality are inseparable, it will for the first time bring forth the courageous stories of many other freedom fighters from over two decades of nonviolent resistance. Together they will inspire a conciliatory message for all of humanity along with an impassioned call for international action to safeguard global human rights and the environment. That is, Aung San Suu Kyi maintains, “if enough of us become voices of hope ourselves.”
This PROJECT is in solidarity with the Occupy movements, the Arab Spring, the student strikes, the immolations in Tibet, and austerity demonstrations the world over. We feel that Burma’s long struggle for freedom, human rights and democracy is a beacon offering a fresh model for global transformation.
For those who make a contribution, this is a unique opportunity to invest in spreading the vital message and strategy of nonviolence to a global audience.
"Every thought, every word, and every action that adds to the positive and the wholesome is a contribution to peace. Each and every one of us is capable of making such a contribution. Let us join hands to try to create a peaceful world where we can sleep in security and wake in happiness." 
- Aung San Suu Kyi
Thank you helping us to achieve the vision - joining your hands with ours.
 
        
Our Team
Alan Clements: Among the first Westerners to ordain as a Buddhist monk in Burma, Alan lived in a monastery for nearly five years training in meditation under the Venerable Mahasi Sayadaw and his successor Sayadaw U Pandita. 
After leaving monastic life he became active in Burma’s struggle for freedom, authoring (and co-authoring) several books on their nonviolent revolution for democracy while raising international awareness through the media, including ABC’s Nightline, CBS News, Time and Newsweek, the Guardian, as well as  delivering a keynote for Amnesty International’s 30th year anniversary.
After 16 years of being blacklisted from Burma for his writings and activism, he was recently “unblacklisted” by Burma’s President. And just days ago, he was granted “official permission” to re-enter the country! 
Summer Starr: Summer has extensive experience as an activist, international speaker, legal observer, environmental lobbyist, organizer in student movements, the Occupy movement in NYC, and across the country. She holds a Masters Degree in Environmental Law and Policy from Vermont Law School, a Masters Degree in Indigenous Politics from the University of Hawai'i, and was a candidate for a District Seat in the Hawaii State House of Representatives.
Marcia Jacobs: Over the past two decades working as a social worker and trauma therapist, Marcia has been creating programs for refugees in conflict and post conflict situations in Bosnia, Kosovo, Afghanistan and Darfur, through The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, UNICEF, and various NGOs, including the International Rescue Committee, founded by Albert Einstein in response to the plight of refugees after WWII. 
Ian MacKenzie: Ian is a new media producer based in Vancouver, BC. He has a background in video journalism, short films, and documentaries, with his work appearing in The New York Times, National Geographic TV, CBC Documentary, The Globe and Mail, Adbusters, and festivals around the world. He is currently co-producing Occupy Love, and is in post-production for the short film Reactor. Ian’s short film The Revolution Is Love was named one of the top 10 Occupy films to watch 2011. 
    
 What we need and how your funds will be spent:
10% of contributions go to feeding the monks and nuns and to an HIV/AIDS clinic in Yangon.
Our priority is to be radically transparent in all that we do. We've broken our  costs down for you below so that when you contribute to this vision you know precisely how your funds will be used.
Our Initial Goal: $25,000  
Step 1: Getting to Burma
Flights r/t: $2,350 / Accommodation:$450 / Ground transport $100 
Gifts for hosts and supporters in Burma past and present: $2000     
As a service based vision, no funds are allocated for salaries or stipends.
Step 2: 28 Days in Burma documenting the Voices of Freedom
Accommodation: $2,800 / Food: $1,800 / Transportation: $1,800 / Translator: $2,800 / Medical: $1000 / Internet/phone: $500 / Internal flights $800
Media: Tablet, recorder, two mics: $2,500 / three 128 gb memory cards  $600. / two 1 TB hard drives: $400 / SD Cards: $ 200 / Contingency Tech Needs: $400.   
Indiegogo’s share of funds, pay pal and credit card processing fees $2,000.
And 10% goes to feed the monks and nuns and to an HIV/AIDS clinic in Yangon to buy food, blankets, mosquito nets, and medicines.
Second Tier Goal: $35,000 
Alan spent six months in Burma in 1995 when producing the original edition of “The Voice of Hope.” The initial $25,000 is just the beginning of this project, covering the most basic costs of a 28 day stay in Burma. In other words, every dollar received beyond $25,000 grants us the privilege of continuing to document as many Voices of Freedom as possible. Thus preserving the priceless insights on nonviolent revolution from some of the most courageous activists alive.    
In addition, we need several full time professionals to transcribe the interviews and a couple of great audio/ video editors. In addition, we need a talented web developer and graphic artist. But for now, we're hoping that we can fill these roles with volunteers or interns who can work with us virtually.
If interested in offering your services please email us your resume today! Thank you.   
Third Tier Stretch Funding: $50,000 + 
Funding at this level will radically expedite the project by securing the services of a production manager, quality book designer, researchers, copy editors, a photo archivist and caption writer, social media expert, and a radical publicist. 
From our hearts, thank you for believing in us and partnering with us to bring "Burma’s Voices of Freedom" to the world now ...and for generations to come.   
          

Additional Ways You Can Help
Beyond monetarily supporting this vision, there are a number of other ways to help us to bring Burma's voices of hope and freedom to the world.  
1. Campaign Ambassadors: We need inspired hearts willing to spread the word of our Campaign worldwide. Please reach out through your personal email lists and social networks and circles, inspiring friends, family and co-workers to join this ACTION, this worldwide peaceful revolution for freedom. 
If you'd like to work with us on a more full time basis please email today.
2. Tech Talents: We would like talented volunteers in the following areas:
* Transcribing interviews 
* Editing interviews 
* Researchers (especially, those who are knowledgeable about Burma)
* Graphic artists (and those skilled in designing book interiors & covers)
* Researching photographs for the book and getting clearances for use 
* Copy editors (print)
* Audio and video editors  
* Web developer (s): talented coders / word press / drupal 7  
* Calling for a brilliant publicist to bring this publication to the world.
3. Calling all Members of the Media: Please carry this story, whether blogs, newspapers, campus circulations, PSA's on community radio or "live reads" by DJ's everywhere in the world. All we ask is that you communicate the vision in a way that reflects unity, reconciliation and hope for ALL the people of Burma. 
Please, print any aspect of anything you see on our site and spread the word.
JOIN US! Have a talent we need? Want to be a part of the movement? 
Send us a simple resumé. We will get back to you quickly.  

From Our Hearts thank you...

story:
Story of My Book

The Silver Lining is an intersection of sexual assault and anxiety in the world of gymnastics.  I venture through the intricacies of the silver medal, the silver between the black and white of life and best of all, the silver lining. I explore how the culture influenced my experiences both inside and outside of the gym's four walls. I welcome you into my most intimate stories and invite you to follow me on my journey of discovering my silver lining, in the hopes that I can help you find your silver lining too.

My name is Serena Pergola, and I am the author of The Silver Lining. I wrote this book to share my story with the world and inspire others to share their stories. I want to build a community of support and empowerment.

My hope is that, in reading this book, you will discover your silver lining, just like I have. In this book, I want to instill the same passion for sexual assault awareness and prevention, as well as, mental health awareness in you that I have within myself. And ultimately, I want you to see this book as a tool to help you find your silver lining.

In this book, you'll learn about trust and empowerment through stories such as:
  • I’m Cured! Oh Wait, There’s No Such Thing
  • The Jagged Path Of Coping And Healing In The Wide World Of Therapy
  • In a World Where You Can Be Anything, Be Kind
I want to share this journey with anyone and everyone who is willing to open themselves up to letting me in. I specifically want to connect with those young gymnasts and parents of gymnasts who share my passion for the invaluable sport of gymnastics. The Silver Lining is a non-fiction book that speaks to athletes and parents who are looking at sexual assault and mental health.

 

The Book - The Silver Lining

The book is written in 3 Parts:

Part One: Looking Backward contains the Introduction, Prologue and Chapters 1 through 10. These chapters narratively set-up my story and explore how gymnastics inside the four walls of the gym sculpted my life. I then delve into how those vulnerabilities led to the three counts of sexual assault I experienced. This section includes How My First Love Became My Undying Addiction and The Break That Changed My Life.

Part Two: Looking Deeper contains Chapters 11 through 17. In these chapters I take a step back to analyze how these vulnerabilities have affected me on a deeper level outside of the gym. I talk about my journey of finding a therapist that was right for me and coping with my experiences in order to uncover them in a new light. This section includes How a Manipulative Doctor and an Inspiring Patient Helped Me Share My Story and We’ve Only Just Scratched the Surface.

Part Three: Looking Forward contains Chapters 18 through 21. This last section brings everything full circle and discusses how to truly and fully identify and embrace your silver lining. This section includes A Letter From My Mom: Open Your Hearts... And Your Ears and Love Yourself and the Others Will Follow.

 

What I Need & What You'll Get

 

This book will be published with New Degree Press. I set up the pre-order tiers to help cover the costs for publishing my book. Money raised will go towards the following:
 
  • The Editor I will work with to revise and publish my manuscript for December, 2019.
  • The Cover Design of my Book - the mockups you see currently are a placeholder!
  • The Layout Design for the interior of my book (Physical Copy, Ebook Formats)
  • The Copyediting for My Book - to help polish the grammar and spelling prior to publication
  • The Launch & Promotion Efforts for my book - when I ultimately publish this winter.


When I pre-sell 100 copies of my book, I will publish. When I pre-sell 150 copies of my book, I will also publish an audiobook. When I pre-sell 200 copies of my book, I will publish a hardcover edition.



I am also offering some exclusive rewards for people who pre-order my book now:

  • You will receive a personally signed copy of my book when I publish
  • A Personal, handwritten thank you note for pre-ordering my book
  • Your Name will appear in a Special, Acknowledgements Section of my book (“With Special Thanks to”)
  • Early access to the Introduction of my Book and my entire manuscript, with the opportunity to review it and give me early feedback
  • The opportunity to help give me feedback and be involved in selecting my cover
  • I will do a book topic/workshop seminar where I will share the experience of writing my book
  • And more...

 

About the Author

Serena Pergola is a recent University of Michigan alumni and an Account Executive at a digital advertising company in Manhattan, New York.

I am a passionate former gymnast of 15 years who is constantly exploring the world of mental health awareness and sexual assault awareness and prevention. I not only explore the culture of gymnastics and how I feel it needs to be changed for the better, but I also explore the world of therapy in coping with the negative effects of this culture.

I am an active individual who spends lots of time with my family and friends and always enjoys a night of wine, cheese and movies. I would love to one day work for a non-profit who supports survivors through their journey of warrior-ship.

For more information you can connect with Serena at spergola@umich.edu and 'Serena Pergola' on Linked In and Facebook, as well as, @serenapergola on Instagram.
 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge with publishing a book is delivering the finished book to the backer, specifically my mailing of the book to you. I have eliminated this risk by building into the campaign the mailing and shipping costs of your signed copies to you within each pre-order tier.

The risk of delivering the pre-sale copies of my book is contingent on the publisher we use. I will be working closely with New Degree Press to make sure we get the earliest possible ship date of the signed book copy to you. We will keep all pre-sale backers up-to-date as my book hits each key milestone and publishes. You will know when the copies of my book you pre-ordered are expected to ship.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please Share my Pre-sale Campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn with your friends, family and network. Please use #TheSilverLining and tag me as well as my publisher, New Degree Press so we can help amplify your efforts.

You can easily share my Pre-Sale Campaign Page via Indiegogo at the top of the page

Please share my book with 5 friends, family members, or co-workers who you think would enjoy it. Please do this as a text message or Direct Message on social media.

 

Thank you so much of all of your love and support! This would not be possible without the community we are building together. 


Let's cope, build and grow together.

Serena Pergola

story:
Update post-campaign

Yes, people - we did it! 
We have enough to make this happen.
We got £790 via this page and people are still promising cheques and cash. 
Please make cheques payable to 'Winkler Media' and send to 
 Winkler Media, Hamilton House, 80 Stokes Croft, Bristol BS1 3QY, UK. 
Everyone who contributes gets a free copy of the Confessions of a Hitch-hiker e-book. 
Here is the original pitch...

Confessions of a Hitch-hiker as an e-book

Published in 1970, and based on true stories from the Sixties, Confessions of a Hitch-hiker, sold 250,000 copies, was optioned as a movie, reprinted several times including in the UK and the US, and translated into several languages - proven entertainment!

  • I am a journalist, and widow of the author, Adrian Reid
  • Confessions of a Hitch-Hiker is a perfect vehicle for an e-book - easy-to-read, engaging and punchy
  • Confessions of a Hitch-Hiker is about female friendship in the freewheeling Sixties. 

Opening chapter - an excerpt 

"I first met Hardy, who became my best flipper and hitch-hiking companion, in Juan-les-Pins, which is in the South of France, in case you don’t know. I was sixteen at the time and had made my way down from London, where I’d had a bit of trouble with a probation officer (not my fault), and after living for a while among the beatnik crowd on the beach I’d moved in with a French painter called Rocco, who was rather special to me.

Rocco was serious about his painting, but not very interested in selling it, so to get money for food we used to go out and try to flog the pictures together, which was good fun. Rocco would stand under the trees with some paintings, looking talented, while I hustled likely-looking customers to come over and take a look.

One evening, I hustled Hardy. She was mooching around by herself, dressed as scruffily as I was – tight jeans and a shirt tied at the waist and no shoes – but I thought she might be an heiress or something, so I went up and gave her the usual chat.

“Fantastic, aren’t they? He’s a budding genius. Buy one now and you’ll never regret it.”

A pair of large, china-blue yes looked at me and smiled. ‘Sorry, couldn’t even afford to buy an ice-cream at the moment,’ Hardy said. 

And that was the beginning of a beautiful friendship." 

- Confessions of a Hitch-hiker by Adrian Reid, excerpt.


Adrian and I

Adrian Reid (author of Confessions of a Hitch-hiker) and I met by chance on the Portobello Road in 1979, when I was a single mother. Despite the 30-year age gap, Adrian and I were soul mates. He died aged 64 in 1986, when I was 33. Now I am 60. Time goes so quickly. I have been thinking of this e-book project since the film director, Pete Tombs, got in touch in 2012. ("I always wanted to know more about the mysterious Mr Reid," he wrote). 


We are ready to publish

The book is typed-up, ready to be converted to an e-book. I am a digital communications specialist so I have the know-how to promote the book. There are only have a few things left to do to make this happen:

  • Superb eye-catching cover
  • Proofing pages
  • Conversion to e-book 
  • YOUR support to get the word out!

We can make this happen

I have the drive to make this happen as well as the technical expertise. Funds raised are to cover proofing, cover design and conversion to e-book. I am donating my marketing skills. 

  • As a freelance journalist and author, I have a proven track record in bringing publishing projects to completion
  • Bett Norris, illustrator (and Wallace & Gromit giant sheep creator!) is designing the book cover, ready to convert the document to digital
  • Creating an e-book is only the start. It has to get noticed, too. I have my own boutique PR, social media and communications  business, so I know what to do  to get a product the attention it deserves.

Winning project

Confessions of a Hitch-hiker is already a much-loved book. 

One online reviewer wrote: "I read this book about 100 times the summer I turned 14. I wanted more than anything to hitch hike across Europe. When I am in Europe, I give rides to hitch hikers."


Other ways you can help

Moral support is worth a lot. Also, the more visits this page gets, the more it helps the campaign, so do share the page with your friends.

Foreword and Chapter One of Confessions of a Hitch-hiker on Facebook. 

Thank you!

Confessions of a Hitch-Hiker is a perfect vehicle for an e-book - easy-to-read, engaging and punchy
 
Confessions of a Hitch-Hiker is about female friendship in the freewheeling Sixties. 


Opening chapter - an excerpt 
"I first met Hardy, who became my best flipper and hitch-hiking companion, in Juan-les-Pins, which is in the South of France, in case you don’t know. I was sixteen at the time and had made my way down from London, where I’d had a bit of trouble with a probation officer (not my fault), and after living for a while among the beatnik crowd on the beach I’d moved in with a French painter called Rocco, who was rather special to me.

Rocco was serious about his painting, but not very interested in selling it, so to get money for food we used to go out and try to flog the pictures together, which was good fun. Rocco would stand under the trees with some paintings, looking talented, while I hustled likely-looking customers to come over and take a look.
One evening, I hustled Hardy. She was mooching around by herself, dressed as scruffily as I was – tight jeans and a shirt tied at the waist and no shoes – but I thought she might be an heiress or something, so I went up and gave her the usual chat.
“Fantastic, aren’t they? He’s a budding genius. Buy one now and you’ll never regret it.”
A pair of large, china-blue yes looked at me and smiled. ‘Sorry, couldn’t even afford to buy an ice-cream at the moment,’ Hardy said. 
And that was the beginning of a beautiful friendship." 
- Confessions of a Hitch-hiker by Adrian Reid, excerpt.



Adrian and I
Adrian Reid (author of Confessions of a Hitch-hiker) and I met by chance on the Portobello Road in 1979, when I was a single mother. Despite the 30-year age gap, Adrian and I were soul mates. He died aged 64 in 1986, when I was 33. Now I am 60. Time goes so quickly. I have been thinking of this e-book project since the film director, Pete Tombs, got in touch in 2012. ("I always wanted to know more about the mysterious Mr Reid," he wrote). 
  We are ready to publish The book is typed-up, ready to be converted to an e-book. I am a digital communications specialist so I have the know-how to promote the book. There are only have a few things left to do to make this happen: 
Superb eye-catching cover

Proofing pages
Conversion to e-book  YOUR support to get the word out!


  We can make this happen I have the drive to make this happen as well as the technical expertise. Funds raised are to cover proofing, cover design and conversion to e-book. I am donating my marketing skills. 


As a freelance journalist and author, I have a proven track record in bringing publishing projects to completion


Bett Norris, illustrator (and Wallace & Gromit giant sheep creator!) is designing the book cover, ready to convert the document to digital

Creating an e-book is only the start. It has to get noticed, too. I have my own boutique PR, social media and communications  business, so I know what to do  to get a product the attention it deserves.


  Winning project
Confessions of a Hitch-hiker is already a much-loved book. 
One online reviewer wrote: "I read this book about 100 times the summer I turned 14. I wanted more than anything to hitch hike across Europe. When I am in Europe, I give rides to hitch hikers."

  Other ways you can help Moral support is worth a lot. Also, the more visits this page gets, the more it helps the campaign, so do share the page with your friends.
Foreword and Chapter One of Confessions of a Hitch-hiker on Facebook. 
 Thank you!

story:
Last Flight Home is a fantasy novel, the first in a trilogy set on a planet called Axis Solan.

The Austringers are falcon-worshipping mountain dwellers who live just fine in their secluded world atop some pretty tall cliffs. Their world is being threatened, however — first by their dying sun and second by an invading force from the north whose land is no longer habitable.

Last Flight Home is the story of a warrior prince who must race home to warn the king — his father — of a treasonous plot and an imminent attack from their displaced northern enemy. But he faces numerous obstacles along the way, including the threat of a menacing troll-like character that’s caught right in the middle of everything. 

Who’s the audience?

This novel can appeal to anyone who loves a good old-fashioned fantasy yarn. It’s filled with action and adventure, a bit of horror, epic battles, and a scary, demented hill-giant who can morph into various creatures and loves to drink the blood of his victims.

What more could you want from a fantasy story? 

The story’s main action is a direct result of natural disasters that force two societies to be at odds with each other. For the main character, it’s also a coming-of-age story.

The audience ranges from those who like a good man vs. nature story to those who like to see an unlikely hero come out on top. Among the novel's themes is the notion of bullying. I’ve created a band of characters who — due to their young age and lack of physical strength — are overlooked by the corrupt powers-that-be.

These young people are strong due to their ability to use their brains as much as, if not more than, their brawn. Despite not being the best of warriors, they still find their place in defending their people and culture from the invading forces.

I wanted to create a hero who survives mostly by his wits and brains — and the help of like-minded friends — and explore the notion that the mind is more powerful than the sword.

Why the campaign?

Possibilities Publishing Company will release my book in 2015. I am raising money to help supplement the production costs:

  • Artwork for the cover and a map of Axis Solan. 
  • Professional editing. Having a book professionally edited is essential to its success. My publisher requires professional editing before it will publish a book, but it's also the only way to make sure my book is as strong as it can be. 
  • Marketing. Although there are a lot of free or low-cost ways to market (social media, for example), many activities cost money, including attending conferences and festivals, upgrading the video trailer, creating signs and other marketing materials for those events, and buying book stock to sell at events. 

I plan to use any extra money I might generate to visit libraries and schools around the country and host readings, performances and Q&As about the novel. I would love it if young readers find my novel interesting and entertaining, especially if it keeps them reading. 

If this book launch is successful, the revenue from its sales will enable me to cover the costs of producing the second book and then the third book in the trilogy. So by supporting this campaign, you are making an investment in me and my work and helping me get started on a new and fulfilling path. 

Risks and rewards

For every writer who makes a profit from his or her book, there are hundreds of equally talented writers who don't make a cent of profit. The fact that I'm planning a trilogy increases the odds that I'll be profitable because series typically do better than individual books, and the final book in a trilogy is often the best seller that then spurs sales of the first two books. 

I also have some advantages over self-published or subsidy-published authors. First and foremost, I have an innovative, flexible and passionate publishing company supporting me. Aside from expert guidance and advice, it has additional marketing platforms and tools that will expand my reach. 

Other ways you can help

If you can't make a financial contribution — or if you do and want to help even more — there are several things you can do: 

  • Share this campaign on your social media platforms and encourage your friends and family to contribute. 
  • Like me on Facebook and repost updates on this campaign and the book.
  • Like Possibilities Publishing Company on Facebook and/or follow the company on Twitter and repost/retweet updates on this campaign and the book. 
  • Attend my events or invite me to yours. For instance, I'm happy to visit book clubs, in person or via Skype. 
CAMPAIGN UPDATE: There has been a slight change in some of the Perks. In four of our offerings, we have listed a "button" as part of the package. As a result of feedback, and various other logistical issues, I have changed the button offering to a Sticker. So, just to be clear, where ever you see a button in a Perk, it will actually be a Sticker. This will be a design that is directly linked to the novel, and, I feel, in this day and age, something that more people will find more uses for than a button. 
I am confident that you are investing in an entertaining and thoughtful work.
Thanks to all who have helped me keep the fire stoked. I would be no where without your generosity, patience, and appreciation.  
- JB

story:
La Novela

El secuestro de un alto funcionario de la O.N.U. en la casa real de Copenhague por el comando ruso Pravda, pone en peligro el tratado de paz a firmarse, sobre una supuesta guerra en la Siberia profunda. Como única exigencia, la difusión por televisión del secuestro en directo para el mundo. Así los telespectadores conocerán sobre manipulaciones políticas y económicas de los principales círculos de poder.
          Casi un año más tarde, llega a manos de un modesto reportero de la televisión danesa importante documentación clasificada, que la agencia de espionaje pretende recuperar a cualquier precio. Ante las misteriosas desapariciones de su colega y otras dos personas, que estuvieron en contacto con esos documentos, el reportero de prensa rosa adquiere conciencia de los peligros, y arriesga su existencia para salvar la vida de un presidente, cuyos intentos de asesinato recogen los comprometedores folios, junto a otros magnicidios perpetrados durante décadas.
          Una agente de servicio secreto emprende una despiadada caza contra el periodista, por Áfríca, Europa y el continente americano. Los métodos empleados por la espía chocan siempre con la nada ortodoxa defensa del perseguido, que sorprenderá hasta a los mismos lectores.

El Autor

Julián Despaigne Rodríguez (nacido en La Habana en 1962) es Licenciado en Leyes en la universidad de su ciudad natal en 1989. En 1996 trasladó su residencia y sus oficios a Copenhague. Periodista freelance en redacciones culturales de emisoras cubanas y danesas, profesor de Historia por la universidad de Odense, Dinamarca; traductor e intérprete de danés, corresponsal en festivales de internacionales de cine. Jurado en el Premio de la Crítica del 28 Festival Internacional de cine de Huesca en el año 2000. Desde el año 2002 reside en Valencia, imparte talleres y cursos de animación lectora en colegios, institutos y universidades. En Madrid, La Rioja, Salamanca, Cataluña, Castilla La Mancha, Alicante o Marruecos. Su libro Soledad en los Pirineos resultó ganador en el XII Premio ciudad de Coria cuentos 2002, publicado al año siguiente. Acordes de la palabra, su segundo libro, un ensayo sobre animación lectora y literatura, se publicó en el 2005. Tunguska es su primera novela.

Una muestra

«Ante cada pregunta de la reportera, solo mudez. Por más que le comenta o apremia, él permanece inmutable. ¿Su actividad en la O.N.U.? Nada. ¿Ha sido mediador en conflictos armados? Más de lo mismo. ¿En qué trabaja en la actualidad? Silencio. La cámara enfoca directo a sus arrugadas mejillas que apenas expresan emoción. ¿Háblenos de su trabajo como mediador?
          Luego, cumpliendo instrucciones, la periodista de TV5 emplea su voz en off, mientras el aburrido semblante del señor Zeit ocupa el centro de la imagen en las pantallas. “El próximo martes se firmará en la capital noruega un crucial acuerdo entre las autoridades de Moscú y los representantes locales de Tetere, poblado de Siberia central, cercano a Vanavara. El pacto tiene por objetivos básicos poner fin al contencioso bélico, posibilitar la reconstrucción, y por último facilitar la explotación racional de los recursos naturales de la zona...”
          Jette Nielsen no comprende nada de lo que lee, los secuestrados no entienden lo que escuchan, y la teleaudiencia de las dos cadenas privadas continúa en ascuas frente a sus televisores. No ofrecen cotilleo, tampoco reality show, les resulta un tedio la jeta triste de ese noruego sentado en el suelo como un vagabundo. De repente una simple palabra, extraña y atrayente, melódica y fugaz, funciona como detonador, incluso para la propia reportera que lo ha leído: Tunguska».

El Objetivo

En esta campaña preventa nos hemos propuesto alcanzar el equivalente a 55 reservas, es decir, 880€, recibiendo quienes participen el libro en su casa sin gastos de envío (en España) antes de que entre en circulación... existiendo incluso la opción de reservar el libro con tu nombre en los agradecimientos por un poco más del precio de venta, como detalle exclusivo.

También, usando la opción BACK IT, podéis realizar donaciones a la edición; opción a través de la cual no se os pedirá dirección de envío porque no conlleva contraprestación de ningún tipo.

Media

Por otro lado, independientemente de que colaboréis realizando vuestra reserva o no, en ocasiones no se puede, sería una inestimable ayuda que os hicieseis eco de esta campaña a través del boca-oreja o por redes sociales... la Cultura, Distrito 93 y Julián Despaigne Rodríguez os lo agradeceremos.

Mil gracias por haberos tomado la molestia de leer toda esta información.

Media

story:
Changing Suns Press

Changing Suns Press is a volunteer-run, collective, anti-authoritarian publishing project. We are committed to the production and dissemination of engaging political, Do-It-Yourself and scholarly publications. We publish both original manuscripts and translations. We are dedicated to the production and dissemination of provocative and engaging print, digital and audio material.

We are raising funds to launch this new anti-authoritarian press. This fundraiser will provide the funds to print our first set of books. Thus, with your support our press will open a new space for radical and alternative publishing.

Learn more about our books and our project at the Changing Suns Press Webpage

Our Collective

Magalí Rabasa: I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I wanted to connect the kinds of rebellious, underground publishing experiments that I’ve accompanied in other parts of the Americas with the everyday conversations I have with comrades and colleagues here in the north.

Peter Garden: I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I have been on the bookselling end of the radical book business for a long time. I am excited to have the opportunity to contribute to a fresh, new press that is seeking to make a contribution to the ideas anti-authoritarian movements are grappling with in the world today. It is truly heartening to see the emergence of a new book-publishing collective on the radical book landscape and I look forward to seeing where we can take this project.  

Jieun Lee: I got involved in Changing Suns Press because the project attracted me with the potential to change how knowledge and ideas travel around the world. Radical ideas that are produced outside of the Euro-American academic world are still hardly visible in the north America. With translations of non-English radical texts into English, I envision more dialogues between radical thinkers and activists around the world to happen.

Chris Kortright: I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I wanted to be a part of the long tradition of anarchist and radical publishing. I also thought that creating a new project that can take seriously both radical and scholarly texts as well as opening up dialogues in north america by bringing in new and different translations.

Michelle Stewart: I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I wanted to help facilitate a space in which we could bring together radical theorists and scholars to share their ideas that promote a more egalitarian world. I hope that Changing Suns Press can join the long and rich tradition of radical publishing and take the ideas of our authors to classrooms and living rooms alike.

Nate Freiburger:  I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I want to help foster a space for intellectual work that is radical, experimental, and presents an alternative to the logic of knowledge production of the market and the north american academy. For me, this project  draws from a long line of independent, anti-authoritarian, and alternative publishing traditions in North and South America that take the ideas and creative work of intellectual production seriously. I hope that Changing Suns can help to foster a space where intellectual production is something more than ideas contained between the covers of our books and something that can become part of the more just, non-heirarchical, and meaningful world we want to help create.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $10,000 which will go to the printing of our first few books.  This will get us started printing and distributing books that will eventually feed back into more books. As a volunteer-run publishing project, none of the money will go to individuals in the Changing Suns Press collective, but instead will go directly to the production and distribution of our material. After this initial fundraising, the sales of our books will lead to the production and distribution of more materials. 

Perks

The perks you will receive for donations are the published material you helped to bring into the world. Primarily we are offering our paperback books and ebooks along with t-shirts and hoodies. We are also excited to have original limited edition prints by one of our cover artists. 


Other Ways You Can Help Changing Suns Press

Besides supporting our press through your donations, there are other ways to help Changing Suns Press:

1) Promote this fundraising campaign and our webpage to your friends, families and networks

2) Connect us to your local independent bookstore and get them to distribute our books. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com )

3) Become a local distributor, vendor or promoter of Changing Suns Press. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com)

4)  Get involved/volunteer with the press. We can always use help copy editing, proof-reading and doing promotion. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com )

5) Submit a manuscript or encourage others to submit exciting manuscripts. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com )

6) Sign up on our mailing list and get your friends, families and networks to sign up also ( changingsunspress.com )

I hope that Changing Suns Press can join the long and rich tradition of radical publishing and take the ideas of our authors to classrooms and living rooms alike.Nate Freiburger:  I got involved in Changing Suns Press because I want to help foster a space for intellectual work that is radical, experimental, and presents an alternative to the logic of knowledge production of the market and the north american academy. For me, this project  draws from a long line of independent, anti-authoritarian, and alternative publishing traditions in North and South America that take the ideas and creative work of intellectual production seriously. I hope that Changing Suns can help to foster a space where intellectual production is something more than ideas contained between the covers of our books and something that can become part of the more just, non-heirarchical, and meaningful world we want to help create.What We Need & What You GetWe are asking for $10,000 which will go to the printing of our first few books.  This will get us started printing and distributing books that will eventually feed back into more books. As a volunteer-run publishing project, none of the money will go to individuals in the Changing Suns Press collective, but instead will go directly to the production and distribution of our material. After this initial fundraising, the sales of our books will lead to the production and distribution of more materials.  PerksThe perks you will receive for donations are the published material you helped to bring into the world. Primarily we are offering our paperback books and ebooks along with t-shirts and hoodies. We are also excited to have original limited edition prints by one of our cover artists.  Other Ways You Can Help Changing Suns Press
Besides supporting our press through your donations, there are other ways to help Changing Suns Press:1) Promote this fundraising campaign and our webpage to your friends, families and networks2) Connect us to your local independent bookstore and get them to distribute our books. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com ) 3) Become a local distributor, vendor or promoter of Changing Suns Press. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com)4)  Get involved/volunteer with the press. We can always use help copy editing, proof-reading and doing promotion. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com )5) Submit a manuscript or encourage others to submit exciting manuscripts. (contact us at info@changingsunspress.com )6) Sign up on our mailing list and get your friends, families and networks to sign up also ( changingsunspress.com )

story:
The Letters Festival


What:

  • The Letters Festival is a three-day creative writing event featuring high-quality independent authors.
  • Through live readings, writing workshops, discussion panels and author talks, The Letters Festival seeks to create an engaging experience focusing on diverse voices and perspectives.
  • The Letters Festival believes in the power of independent literature and is committed to increasing its role in Atlanta’s rich artistic culture. 

When:

  • Thursday, November 14 — Saturday, November 16, 2013

Schedule:

THURSDAY, November 14 @ Mother

  • 8:00 PM: Readings from Jericho Brown, Matt DeBenedictis, Kim Henderson, Jacob Scheier

FRIDAY, November 15 @ The Goat Farm Arts Center

  • 6:30 PM: Author talk with Roxane Gay
  • 8:00 PM: Readings from Scott McClanahan, Mary Miller, Ajay Vishwanathan, Monic Ductan

SATURDAY, November 16 @ The Goat Farm Arts Center

  • 2:00 PM: Poetry writing workshop with Jacob Scheier
  • 2:00 PM: Fiction writing workshop with Kim Henderson
  • 4:00 PM: Discussion panel, “Diverse Voices in Independent Literature” with Roxane Gay, Matthew Salesses, Mary Miller, Chad Prevost
  • 8:00 PM: Readings from Blake Butler, Roxane Gay, Matthew Salesses, Jenny Sadre-Orafai

Founders:

The Letters Festival was founded by a group of writers and artists committed to inspiring the community through the power of the written word.


For more information:

www.thelettersfestival.org



 

                             ____________________________________________

  

    

  

Author bios:

  • Jericho Brown is the recipient of the Whiting Writers Award and fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts, the Radcliffe Institute at Harvard University, the Bread Loaf Writers’ Conference, and the Krakow Poetry Seminar in Poland. Brown is an Assistant Professor at Emory University. His poems have appeared in journals and anthologies including, The American Poetry Review, The Believer, jubilat, Oxford American, Ploughshares, A Public Space, Tin House, and 100 Best African American Poems. His first book, PLEASE (New Issues), won the American Book Award.
  • Blake Butler is the author of the novel There Is No Year, the novella Ever, and the novel-in-stories Scorch Atlas. He edits “the internet literature magazine blog of the future” HTMLGiant, as well as two journals of innovative text, Lamination Colony and No Colony. He lives in Atlanta.
  • Matt DeBenedictis lives in Atlanta, Georgia. He is the founder of the press Safety Third Enterprises and is the author of three chapbooks, including Congratulations! There’s No Last Place If Everyone Is Dead.
  • Monic Ductan’s writing has appeared in Prime Number Magazine, DOGZPLOT, Crab Creek Review, San Pedro River Review, FRiGG, and several other journals. Monic’s fiction has made the honorable mention list in Glimmer Train’s Short Story Award for New Writers competition (May 2013). She was also a finalist for the Diana Woods Memorial Award in creative non-fiction (spring, 2013) and a finalist in fiction for the 42nd Annual Agnes Scott College Writers’ Festival Contest.
  • Roxane Gay’s writing appears or is forthcoming in Black Warrior Review, Mid-American Review, Cream City Review, Annalemma, McSweeney's (online), and others. She is the co-editor of PANK, an assistant professor of English at Eastern Illinois University. Her first collection, Ayiti, was released in 2011. 
  • Kim Henderson is the author of The Kind of Girl, which won the Seventh Annual Rose Metal Press Short Short Chapbook Contest. Her stories have appeared in Tin House, H_NGM_N, Cutbank, River Styx, Chamber Four, The Southeast Review, New South, and elsewhere. She lives with her husband on a mountain in Southern California, where she chairs the Creative Writing program at Idyllwild Arts Academy.
  • Scott McClanahan is an American writer and filmmaker. He lives in Beckley, West Virginia and is the author of five books: Stories, Stories II, Stories V!, The Collected Works of Scott McClanahan Vol. 1 and Crapalachia.
  • Mary Miller is the author of a story collection, Big World, and a chapbook, Less Shiny. She lives in Austin, where she is a Michener Fellow at the University of Texas.
  • Chad Prevost is the author of White-Feathered Bodies, A Walking Cliche Coins a Phrase, Snapshots of the Perishing World, and Greatest Hits. Prevost is co-founder and Editorial Director of C&R Press, an independent press dedicated to publishing new voices.
  • Jenny Sadre-Orafai is the author of four chapbooks. Recent poetry has appeared in PANK, RHINO, The Bakery, Sixth Finch, ILK, and iO: A Journal of New American Poetry. Recent prose has appeared in The Rumpus, Delirious Hem, The Los Angeles Review, and South Loop Review. She is co-founding editor of Josephine Quarterly and an Associate Professor of English at Kennesaw State University.
  • Matthew Salesses is the author of I'm Not Saying, I'm Just Saying, a novella, The Last Repatriate, two chapbooks, Our Island of Epidemics and We Will Take What We Can Get, and two forthcoming ebooks, Different Racisms and All-American Bear Terrorizes Canada. He has written for The New York Times, NPR, The Rumpus, Glimmer Train, American Short Fiction, and elsewhere. He is currently the Fiction Editor and a Contributing Writer at The Good Men Project.
  • Jacob Scheier is a poet and journalist from Toronto. His debut collection, More to Keep Us Warm (ECW Press) won the 2008 Governor General's award for English language poetry. Scheier's poems have been published in literary journals and magazines across North America, including Descant, Geist and Rattle, and have been heard on CBC Radio. He is also the co-winner of New York Community Media Alliance Award for best feature article in an independent publication, and is a regular contributor to Toronto’s NOW Magazine. His latest poetry collection, Letter from Brooklyn, was published in Spring 2013 with ECW Press. 
  • Ajay Vishwanathan has work published or forthcoming in over ninety literary journals, including The Minnesota Review, Southern Humanities Review, Smokelong Quarterly, and The Baltimore Review. One of the editors of Foundling Review, Ajay is the author of From a Tilted Pail, a forthcoming short story collection from Queen's Ferry Press. He lives in Atlanta with his wife and twin girls.

story: My name is Geoff Dale, a writer based in Woodstock, Ontario, Canada. My campaign is quite straightforward - write a non-fiction book on the life of Shemp Howard, one of the original Three Stooges but sadly remembered as the Forgotten Stooge. Through research and contacts with his remaining friends and family members, I will look at his career in the early days, before, during and after his stint(s) with the trio.  He was an innovator and responsible for many of the trio's trademark moves and in addition billed himself as 'the ugliest man in Hollywood.' That last strange description made him a much sought after commodity in the business. Shemp is apparently also Jeopardy's Alex Trebek's favorite Stooge. I will need about $2,500, none of which will cover my expense in terms of time spent researching and writing. Firstly there is a copyright license to be purchased from C3 Entertainment Inc. in Los Angeles. I bought one for a fiction I wrote about Larry Fine - it imagines him winning the junior lightweight boxing championship of the world, weeks before the Great Depression hits. In addition there will likely be some travel to do research and possibly acquire materials, photos for the book.The perks, again quite simple: the joy of reading a book on the life of a man few know anything of - a vaudevillian who helped transform comedy in the early 20th Century and a pioneer in entertainment. More tangible perks - I will attempt to get a reduced rate of purchase for supporters - whether the book is published or self-published.  If I don't reach my goal, I will make up the difference with my own funds. Your contribution will make it possible to pass the first step - acquiring the necessary license. Beyond that, it will allow me to spend the needed time on the project, which I hope to finish writing in a year. If there is enough funding, it will go to a professional editor. In the end I hope my book will fill a gap - provide people interested in popular culture with a slice of real history. I've been a writer for nearly 40 years and this project is a genuine passion. With your help, I can get started. Many thanks in advance for your time and consideration. - Geoff

story:
Hacer periodismo de opinión en en Colombia no es fácil. Los pocos medios nacionales que hay son de los mismos dueños. Medios que tienen plazas escasas para columnistas y destinadas siempre a personas muy específicas que pueden opinar siempre y cuando no interfieran con los intereses o socios del medio.

ConlaOrejaRoja nace de la necesidad de una ventana a la opinión, que le permitiera a otras personas con unos puntos de vistas igualmente válidos salir al debate público y contribuir con sus argumentos o hipótesis a la construcción de una sociedad más crítica, que analiza y cuestiona lo que otros callan. 

Surgimos ante la necesidad de un espacio para la promoción del respeto por el otro y la diferencia, porque aquí no nos interesa cual es la ideología del columnista, sino que tenga el derecho a expresar sus ideas y entienda que podemos convivir con la diferencia si tenemos una actitud tolerante, incluyente y pluralista.

Ha sido un primer año donde han escrito más de 300 columnistas de distintas partes de Colombia y el mundo (España, Argentina, México, Estados Unidos, Venezuela, Canadá, etc) 

Aportando su visión a una discusión abierta que nos ha llenado de experiencias gratificantes, conocimientos nuevos y aprendizajes que hemos ido aplicando al mejoramiento continuo de este medio, de este vehículo para potenciar la libertad de expresión.

También realizamos en alianza con distintas instituciones Conversatorios ConlaOrejaRoja, eventos para el encuentro de la sociedad con los expertos donde generamos discusiones tales como: “¿Estaría preparada Colombia para el posconflicto?“, “¿Cómo se está haciendo Periodismo de opinión en Colombia?”, “¿Ser madre es un impedimento para educarse?”. Eventos que nos han permitido sostener de algún modo los gastos que devienen de un proyecto como estos.  

 

Sin embargo, el crecimiento de nuestro flujo y el incremento de los lectores (más de medio millón de usuarios único al mes) han generado la necesidad de implementar distintas mejoras tanto en la página web (pago de un servidor dedicado que permita mayor estabilidad y mejor respuesta, diseño de site a medida, implementación de mejoras en la experiencia de usuario) como en los implementos de trabajo (adecuación de oficina).

De igual modo, nuestro objetivo también es poder recompensar a los columnistas que han confiado sus textos en nuestra iniciativa, convencidos de que una sociedad más crítica se logra a través de una libertad de expresión realmente libre, donde nadie estorbe por ser de esta o aquella ideología, por pensar una cosa o criticar otra; y  a todo el equipo de trabajo (director, dos editores, relacionista público, diseñadora y community manager) que día a día trabajan en este proyecto porque creen en su causa, sin esperar nada a cambio.

Para todo esto necesitamos tu colaboración, no importa que tan grande sea el monto que puedes donar, sino la intención de contribuir y valorar lo que hacemos como un producto valioso y que merece continuidad en el tiempo.
